newsitem.title: UK: NATO opens new Navy HQ for crisis management.
newsitem.headline: NATO opens new Navy HQ for crisis management.

text.p: NATO on Tuesday opened a new naval headquarters to provide a high-speed response to crises from the Atlantic to the Baltic.
The new maritime nerve centre just north of London has up to 18 frigates, destroyers and minesweepers on call to be dispatched to trouble spots.

"We can react quickly. We have standing forces ready and available. They are a core on which we can then expand," said NATO spokesman Jonathan Worthington at the opening ceremony for the new headquarters at Northwood, near London.
"This will now be NATO's principal maritime headquarters this side of the Atlantic. Any crisis in this area -- we will deal with it," he added.

The newly named Atlantic building, which marks the end of the first stage of NATO (North Atlantic Treaty Organisation) restructuring after the end of the Cold War, has a staff of 220 from 10 NATO countries.
The ships supplied by the member states are rotated on a six-monthly basis.
Their forces were already involved in NATO's Operation Sharp Guard which enforced the arms embargo against former Yugoslavia.
They are now back on duty in the Atlantic but can return to the Adriatic should the situation change.
The new headquarters were officially opened by American General Jack Sheehan, NATO's supreme allied commander, Atlantic.

Underlining the need for NATO to adapt to its new role of co-operating with its former Warsaw Pact enemies in the Partnership for Peace programme, he said: "We can no longer afford to view NATO in East-West terms."
"Collective security does work," he told the top naval brass assembled from alliance countries
After the opening ceremony, NATO delegates sat down with their new East European partners for a seminar on how best to tackle the maritime problems they face together.
These range from fishery patrols and oil rig protection to the counter-terrorism measures and intelligence sharing needed across the continent to combat arms smuggling.
"Terrorism is a cross-border affair. It makes sense to try and deal with the problem together," Worthington said as the two sides met behind closed doors.
Northwood is also the command headquarters masterminding Britain's new joint rapid deployment force of elite troops that can be flown speedily to the troublespots of the world.
